Title: Boredom Repetition and Meaning
Post_text:
I think boredom is a theme that can be found throughout Warhol's body of work. It's in the way he uses repetition. There is a point at which the object (the Empire State Building in the film, the electric chair, the can of soup) loses meaning as an object, and that lets you see it, and the art, in different ways. I think it's especially interesting to notice how you relate differently to the work once you've crossed this threshold. 
I think what you describe and definitely Warhol does is similar to Automatic Writing that writers used to do a century ago. To try to connect with your deepest feelings. The work of art should come from the soul and not the mind. The unconscious that Freud describes as the "id" that is the set of uncoordinated instinctual trends. 
I hadn't thought of automatic writing, but yes, absolutely. I don't think the mind disengages completely with Warhol's repetition. Rather, with the loss of meaning comes new meaning, you see the form rather than the function of the object. 
Yes, you got a good point ther because meaning cannot be constructed without the active participation of the mind. But on the other hand, Warhol said "I want to be a machine". There is some confusion to that; Warhol wanted actually to be the machine that is stripped of a conscious mind? What did a machine symbolise to him? Only the repetition pattern? What do you think?
I think this is part of it. He is, in a way, taking his agency out of his artwork, stripping his meaning out, but this makes the viewer's agency stronger. In the end, it is us, standing before light colored repetitions of the electric chair, dollar signs or soup cans, who will first lose their meaning and relationship to the real world object, and be forced into new meanings and new ways of seeing. I'm not sure this was what Warhol wanted to do, but he was more aware than many artists of the effects his work had on the audience.

If you have not visited this website, be prepared for subtlety, contemplation, and the infinite luxury of boredom. Finally, I also see Warhol's screen tests as a challenge- not only to the subject, being faced with the task of sitting in front of video camera for whatever length of time, but also for the viewer, who is faced with the decision whether or not to watch the film, which is slowed down from 24 to 16 frames per second.

It's interesting to consider what cinema could have been if Hollywood hadn't colonized it. Or what television could have been. Or today as we watch The Internet that brought us freedom from old media's commodity culture being slowly recolonized by that very old media. Perhaps the dominant use of a media becomes its default, and alternate uses, like Andy's Screen Tests, become contentious others.

Title: Andy's Alternative Cinema
Post_text: Of course we call Andy's filmmaking alternate. But that almost doesn't put a fine enough point on it. The history of media is the repeating story of wild, game changing, Utopian dreaming, innovation, that is colonized and domesticated to... well... to present the banal culture Andy celebrated in the pursuit of selling the products he immortalized: Coca Cola, Soap, etc. About already enslaved media like Radio, Film & Television we can ponder "what if?" About The Internet, currently under the lash, but not yet completely domesticated, we can battle over Net Neutrality. Andy may have idolized celebrity, but his filmmaking was about as un-Hollywood as one can imagine. What would our world, our media, and our culture be like in some alternate reality where "Hollywood Filmmaking" never really took hold, and style was dominated by "Warhol Filmmaking"? When I look back at the Screen Tests of half a century ago I see Andy prefiguring aesthetic pursuits ranging from Bill Viola's oeuvre to Marina Abramovic's The Artist is Present. We often think of Andy as pop superficiality, yet the Screen Tests offer an intensity of lived presence that Hollywood Filmmaking doesn't dare consider.

Title: Warhol and me: a basic values difference?
Post_text:
Watching the videos for the first week, I realized that part of what is challenging for me around Warhol's work boils down to a fundamental values difference between us. He seems to be captivated by not only the concept of celebrity but also the mainstream (I'm thinking of Campbell's soup, etc.). I hope to learn more in this course and figure out what interesting take he has on these concepts but so far it appears to me that he is just fueling the value of celebrity worship and the mainstream. I find this hard to get behind. I suspect that I am missing his point so I have tried to view his work through different lenses: Freudian, anthropological, etc. but if I have to work this hard to try to find an angle that says something interesting, I feel that I am likely to be putting words in his mouth, so to speak. Is his work just too ambiguous for my taste? Possibly. 
I'm glad to see that I'm not alone. I just don't "get" his work. It's interesting but taken individually none of his works seem particularly well done or innovative. And as a body of work I'm left thinking that it's such a waste of talent. He's a fascinating individual but he seems to just embody celebrity for its own sake. 
You are definately not alone, most people have the same problem when they come in contact with pop art, including me! So, first of all, I think a mistake most of us do, not only about Warhol and Pop Art but for art in general, is that we think based on today. It's totally normal of course, but, to comprehend the art of the past better, we should consider the circumstances at the time the work was produced. For example, the era in which Warhol started working, was post war America. The States had just started emerging dynamically after WW 2, while most of the other countries that were involved suffered great damage. Industrialization was growing RAPIDLY and money started flowing in. All this was new to the people of the country so it must have been something fascinating, the "American Dream". Everybody got infatuated with these new things, whether it was mass produced things or celebrities, but in reality, all it created was an illusion of fulfilment, and that's exactly what Warhol and other pop artists critisize or emancipate. For example, by multiplying pictures of Marylin Monroe -and other celebrities- he took away ALL meaning from her. He emphasized on the symbol, the icon that Hollywood had created, not the human Marylin. He said he loved all things pop, but at the same time, I believe he completely understood the emptiness of it all and that's why he liked it so much, because thanks to that, he could hide comfortably behind a persona. After all he was very shy, as far as I know. And all of this is reflected on the way he was using to make his works, screenprint, so the works looked like they were manifactured in a factory, not made by hand. As for the depth of his work, there was nothing specific. Not in the meaning of philosophical backgrounds ect, at least. I believe that in order to understand pop art, we just have to think about life and our own experiences and let go, because what's happening now in the world and pop culture, is what was happening then, multiplied by 100! And that's another mistake we often do, we try to find a meaning in everything and we get too deep in theories and histories. Sometimes a painting can be just aesthetically pleasing and I don't think it diminishes its value, we just have to see it for what it is. And pop art is all about appearance, surface and color! So that's my view, or at least part of it, since it's a huge discussion! I am by no means an expert, but I have been reading about pop art for quite a few years now so I think I could give you an idea of what it's all about. Of course, from now on it's up to you, but I would encourrage you to keep on exploring it, it's very interesting. 

 Always consider Warhol one of those people who can fully understand the time in which they were living, the hole society and the future projection of his own present. The introductory video to the theme of celebrities by Glyn Davis confirmed me this personal appreciation. Warhol understood the consumer society and gave new products to consume: new celebrities, new artworks as close to them as the products they saw on television. The very same boxes of soap that the working class could see at the supermarket. He began as a collector of portraits of famous actors and ended being acreator of new celebrities. Warhol predicted the new purpose of the twentieth-century American society, everyone wants to be famous and everyone can be famous. There is a new paradise for this society: the celebrity, hollywood, to became famous no matter what. And he also gave a new hell, the other side of the coin: murders, electric chairs and accidents. The other protagonists of his artworks and the media.

Maybe I am expecting such durability as a determining criteria of highly valued art and maybe that is appropriate. Title: Practicalities of Thermal Equilibrium
Post_text:
I understand, or at least I think I understand, the concept of thermal equilibrium described for Hopfield and Boltzmann nets. Critically for my question I understand that the net doesn't settle down to a single state, but instead to a distribution of possible configurations. I also understand how the update rule works. So here is my confusion: we run the update rule over and over and we settle to equilibrium, but how do we know (1) how many times we need to update to reach equilibrium or similarly (2) how do we know we are in thermal equilibrium? I understand we can sample the states, but it seems to me there are $$2^N$$ possible states (for $$N$$ units), finding an unbiased sample seems long/impossible? We'd have to run the update rule a lot... I guess another way that could ask my question: When we are updating how do we know we are bouncing around in equilibrium vs still settling? This information seems hidden to us.
Good observation. In the general case, we don't know. If we're running a Markov chain to try to simulate getting to equilibrium, in the general case we don't know when we've gotten there (when we've reached "mixing"). We can make some educated guesses, though. There are entire courses and books about the issue. (Actually I think for deterministic Hopfield nets we can tell we're at equilibrium. Once every variable is happy and doesn't want to change its state to a lower energy state, we're at equilibrium. But if variables are stochastic, in the general case we can't know if we're at equilibrium.)
I'm not an expert in this field, but my first guess in practice, given a random walk on binary vectors, would be to pick a few sets of coordinates, and see whether the projections to those coordinates has settled down using a chi-squared test to compare the middle third to the last third of the path. There is a lot of interesting mathematical work which has been done on perfect sampling procedures. I don't know how much of it has practical significance, but you can find a survey of part of the literature at [David Wilson's site][1]. Unfortunately that page seems to be about 8 years old, and many of the links are broken. Here are a few toy examples of exact sampling given a different source of randomness than the target. 1) Suppose you have an unfair coin which is heads with an unknown probability $$p$$, and you want to sample from the Bernoulli distribution $$B#MATH$$ to lose -- the last person to receive the ball is perfectly sampled from a uniform distribution, even if you don't know what $$n$$ is. It's a nice puzzle to prove this with no computation necessary. Again, the probability that this process has not terminated drops exponentially in the number of steps, with a rate which depends on $$n$$. Those are warm-ups for the technique of ["coupling from the past"][2] which was Wilson's thesis. [1]: #URLREF#URLREF~dbwilson/exact/ [2]: #URLREF#URLREF
The problem is, you can "settle down" in one part of the space, leaving another part of the space totally unexplored. If you think you have two sample sets from the true distribution, and you compare them, and they look wildly dissimilar, then you probably don't actually have two sample sets from the true distribution. But if you have two sample sets and they look similar, they might both be from the true distribution, or they might both be from some other distribution that is not the true distribution. I think of Markov Chain Monte Carlo as being kind of like exploring a physical space, where you don't know know anything about it. So you're exploring the haunted house. You wander through doors, and you find the kitchen with the bloody tiles, the cobwebby drawing room, the sinister living room, a bedroom with eerie music and mice running over your feet, and so forth. And your friend wanders around, and he finds the same rooms. So you might conclude that you've explored the entire space. And maybe you have, but maybe you missed that little tiny hidden trapdoor to the dungeon! Similarly, with a Markov chain, you might miss a low-probability transition to a high-probability space.

The way I see it is like this: Normal feed-forward networks have no sense of "time", unless your data input is a time based representation - I'll get to the differences in a bit. In recurrent networks, when you update the network to the next "step", I like to think of it as a time "step". As the inputs change over time, the network sees these changes in a certain order at a certain time "step". This allows the network to respond not only to the current inputs, but because of the recurrent connections - specifically ones that do not go "forward" towards the output layer, we are able to retain some of the "information" from previous inputs. I believe the power of recurrent networks is not so much just "memory" or memory over time, but how it can achieve this. This goes back to my first statement that a normal feed-forward network can still model/predict things over "time" if you provide it inputs over "time". But this type of network is limited to how much "memory" it can "see" based on how you format the input. In a recurrent network, it could potentially "remember" information from the very first input sequence. The recurrent connections, and actually the weights themselves #MATH, control how much "memory" is "remembered". This makes them much more powerful, because the network itself can be trained to "remember" as much or as little of the information from the time-sequence inputs as the training dictates. Back to your original question. For example, a prediction on a time sequence that only had a direct relationship to the very first input in the sequence might be more suitable for a recurrent network because a feed forward network that had all of the inputs would probably weight the rest of the inputs very low and thus have not much affect on the output. As explained in the lecture, we insert into the ROB from the decode stage.  Fine, sounds good.  But the pipeline diagrams (say L6S4 slide 31, the IIOI processor) showed something different.  Look at cycle 4, as an example.  Instruction 3 is in decode stage, and the top half of the slide agrees.  The lower half does not have the number 3 in the "D" column, probably for brevity, but the instruction is really there.  So why don't we see instruction 3 appearing in the ROB for the next cycle, cycle 5?  Why did we not insert from the decode stage, as promised? Because that would be incorrect :)  The way I see it now, is that in fact, the decode stage IS sending the insert signals towards the ROB, but since we'll stall the frontend of the pipe, we won't strobe this insert into the ROB.  If we did, then a stalled frontend would enter multiple entries into the ROB. So the precise rule is: We insert into the ROB from the decode step.  However, if we can't issue in this cycle, then (besides skipping the the strobing of the PC and the IR), we also skip the strobing of the ROB insert.  Note however, that we might still strobe an ROB remove, if the commit stage succeeds in committing something, so it's not the whole ROB clock signal that is masked, just the insert selectively.

Title: L5S3 : What are the advantages if any of pulling the Commit point earlier in the pipeline
Post_text:
Having a commit point later in the pipeline seems logical since most operations have been completed.  However, it was also pointed out that pulling the commit point earlier has been done in a few processors. Just wondering what is the advantage of having the commit point at an earlier stage in the pipeline?
On second thoughts, it could be that it helps us in situations where we have Out-of-Order Writebacks. Pulling a Commit point early in the pipeline may help in maintaining precise exceptions.  
The way I understand it, is that in the simplest case, you want every pipe #MATH to have the same number of pipeline steps.  This is a waste of time, if you have a one cycle ALU, and a four cycle multiplier: the ALU will have to be followed by three idle pipeline steps.  You have choices: you can build a true out-of-order processor, with reorder buffer and multiple register files.  Or, you can sacrifice precise exceptions. But if you dislike both of these, then pulling the commit point early is your last resort: in that case, the processor must have equal number of steps between the front and the commit point, but you can still have a varying number of steps after the commit point.  So this is a fairly simple in-order design, but you can still have a long multiply pipe.  You won't need reorder buffer or multiple register files, just a scoreboard, and you can have precise exceptions.

As you correctly point out, the Cache line is going to be evicted ( since it was reserved for Address 0 ), and then refilled with the data for 4096.   You may think of this as though the Cache line at address 4096 was initially in an Invalid state initially and then you have a read miss, therefore the transition would occur from the "I" to the "S" state as per the MSI state machine ( for a Read miss ).  If you had a Load word at time 8 for the address 0, then you would have seen the state machine to remain in "Modified" state. Regards, Pushkal

You are correct, I think that if the cache was in MESI, then I would suspect that the line would be set to E in directory after the initial read miss.
